title: How to Clean Plant Containers

steps.headline: Gather all the containers that need cleaning.
steps.description: Throw away any containers with cracks, chips or signs of weakness.Terracotta containers which are cracked or broken can be used as broken pieces at the base of plant containers to help with drainage.

steps.headline: Wear appropriate clothing.
steps.description: Wear protective gloves. Wearing gloves is important when cleaning plant containers because you will be handling bacteria, fungi and bleach. You do not want bleach to irritate your skin. Wear old clothes in case the bleach solution splashes on them. Also, wear goggles to avoid getting the solution into your eyes.

steps.headline: Remove the debris with the stiff brush.
steps.description: Scrubbing off the debris removes as much loose dirt as possible from the pot. Removing this superficial dirt will accelerate the soaking process.

steps.headline: Make the bleach and water solution.
steps.description: Mix 9 parts water and 1 part household bleach or detergent. Using bleach or detergent will remove bacteria and fungi that could prove problematic for the new plants.

steps.headline: Submerge the containers in the solution for 10 to 15 minutes.
steps.description: Check whether the residue is easy to remove. If not, soak for longer until the dirt is easy to remove. Do not be tempted to use more bleach as this can damage your containers. Let terracotta containers lie in the solution a little longer to disinfect thoroughly.

steps.headline: Wash the containers in the solution.
steps.description: Dip the stiff brush into the solution and gently scrub inside and outside of each container.

steps.headline: Rinse the plant containers with clean water.
steps.description: Rinsing the containers with clean water will remove all traces of cleaning chemicals.Make sure to rinse at least 2 times to remove any bleach residue. You don't want your new plants to absorb any chemicals.

methods.name: Drying, Storing and Reusing the Containers

steps.headline: Dry thoroughly before storing.
steps.description: Moisture can encourage growth of bacteria or mildew, so ensure each container is dry first. Let the containers air dry in the sun.

steps.headline: Store the containers in a clean, dry place.
steps.description: Group by size and stack in neat piles in a clean, dry place such as a greenhouse. Containers made from breakable should, ideally, be stored individually and not stacked. All clean containers should be stored separately from dirty ones to prevent the transfer of bacteria to the clean pot.

steps.headline: Reuse the containers.
steps.description: Your plant containers are now ready to be filled with soil and plants.

text: Preparing to Clean the Containers Gather all the containers that need cleaning. Throw away any containers with cracks, chips or signs of weakness.Terracotta containers which are cracked or broken can be used as broken pieces at the base of plant containers to help with drainage. Wear appropriate clothing. Wear protective gloves. Wearing gloves is important when cleaning plant containers because you will be handling bacteria, fungi and bleach. You do not want bleach to irritate your skin. Wear old clothes in case the bleach solution splashes on them. Also, wear goggles to avoid getting the solution into your eyes. Remove the debris with the stiff brush. Scrubbing off the debris removes as much loose dirt as possible from the pot. Removing this superficial dirt will accelerate the soaking process. Soaking the Plant Containers Make the bleach and water solution. Mix 9 parts water and 1 part household bleach or detergent. Using bleach or detergent will remove bacteria and fungi that could prove problematic for the new plants. Submerge the containers in the solution for 10 to 15 minutes. Check whether the residue is easy to remove. If not, soak for longer until the dirt is easy to remove. Do not be tempted to use more bleach as this can damage your containers. Let terracotta containers lie in the solution a little longer to disinfect thoroughly. Wash the containers in the solution. Dip the stiff brush into the solution and gently scrub inside and outside of each container. Rinse the plant containers with clean water. Rinsing the containers with clean water will remove all traces of cleaning chemicals.Make sure to rinse at least 2 times to remove any bleach residue. You don't want your new plants to absorb any chemicals. Drying, Storing and Reusing the Containers Dry thoroughly before storing. Moisture can encourage growth of bacteria or mildew, so ensure each container is dry first. Let the containers air dry in the sun. Store the containers in a clean, dry place. Group by size and stack in neat piles in a clean, dry place such as a greenhouse. Containers made from breakable should, ideally, be stored individually and not stacked. All clean containers should be stored separately from dirty ones to prevent the transfer of bacteria to the clean pot. Reuse the containers. Your plant containers are now ready to be filled with soil and plants.

Throw away any containers with cracks, chips or signs of weakness.Terracotta containers which are cracked or broken can be used as broken pieces at the base of plant containers to help with drainage.
Wear appropriate clothing.
Wear protective gloves.
Wearing gloves is important when cleaning plant containers because you will be handling bacteria, fungi and bleach.
You do not want bleach to irritate your skin.
Wear old clothes in case the bleach solution splashes on them.
Also, wear goggles to avoid getting the solution into your eyes.
Remove the debris with the stiff brush.
Scrubbing off the debris removes as much loose dirt as possible from the pot.
Removing this superficial dirt will accelerate the soaking process.
Soaking the Plant Containers Make the bleach and water solution.
Mix 9 parts water and 1 part household bleach or detergent.
Using bleach or detergent will remove bacteria and fungi that could prove problematic for the new plants.
Submerge the containers in the solution for 10 to 15 minutes.
Check whether the residue is easy to remove.
If not, soak for longer until the dirt is easy to remove.
Do not be tempted to use more bleach as this can damage your containers.
Let terracotta containers lie in the solution a little longer to disinfect thoroughly.
Wash the containers in the solution.
Dip the stiff brush into the solution and gently scrub inside and outside of each container.
Rinse the plant containers with clean water.
Rinsing the containers with clean water will remove all traces of cleaning chemicals.Make sure to rinse at least 2 times to remove any bleach residue.
You don't want your new plants to absorb any chemicals.
Drying, Storing and Reusing the Containers Dry thoroughly before storing.
Moisture can encourage growth of bacteria or mildew, so ensure each container is dry first.
Let the containers air dry in the sun.
Store the containers in a clean, dry place.
Group by size and stack in neat piles in a clean, dry place such as a greenhouse.
Containers made from breakable should, ideally, be stored individually and not stacked.
All clean containers should be stored separately from dirty ones to prevent the transfer of bacteria to the clean pot.
Reuse the containers.
Your plant containers are now ready to be filled with soil and plants.
tyn_section: Large container or bathtub for the solution
